GB.intro: The UK uses the +44 calling code. UK numbers are often written with a leading 0 domestically (the trunk prefix). When calling the UK from abroad, you typically drop that leading 0 and dial +44 instead.

emergencyNumbers.notes: 999 and 112 both connect to the UK emergency services.

tips: Domestic UK format often starts with 0 (e.g. 020…, 07…). International format typically removes that 0.
UK mobile numbers usually start with 07 domestically; from abroad that becomes +44 7…
If you’re calling from a mobile, using +44 is the simplest option (no need to know your exit code).
commonMistakes: Dialling +44 0… (keeping the domestic 0 after +44) — this often fails.
Mixing spaces/punctuation into a tel: link instead of a clean E.164 number.

faqs.q: Do I drop the leading 0 when calling the UK internationally?
faqs.a: Usually yes. The leading 0 is a domestic trunk prefix and is typically omitted when dialling from abroad.

US.intro: The United States uses calling code +1 (NANP). +1 is shared across multiple countries/territories, so the area code is essential for identifying the destination.

emergencyNumbers.notes: 911 is the standard emergency number in the United States.

tips: US numbers are commonly written as (AAA) BBB-CCCC. In international/E.164 format this becomes +1AAABBBCCCC.
+1 is shared (NANP). If you only have “+1 …” without context, you can’t always infer the country/territory.
For click-to-call links, prefer tel:+1… without spaces for maximum compatibility.
commonMistakes: Assuming +1 always means the USA (it can also be Canada and other NANP regions).
Dropping the area code (required for most calls).

faqs.a: No. +1 is part of the North American Numbering Plan and is shared by multiple countries and territories (including Canada and others).

FR.intro: France uses calling code +33. French numbers are usually written domestically with a leading 0; when calling from abroad, you generally drop that 0 and use +33.

emergencyNumbers.notes: 112 is the EU-wide emergency number; France also uses 15 (medical), 17 (police), and 18 (fire).

tips: Domestic numbers often look like 0X XX XX XX XX. International format commonly becomes +33 X XX XX XX XX.
Using +33 on mobiles is usually the easiest approach (no exit code needed).

faqs.a: Domestically, yes — the leading 0 is common. Internationally, you typically drop it and dial +33 instead.
